headline: Bedwetting treatable, can be hereditary –Paediatrician
summarized_story:
Toluwalope KareemA consultant pediatrician/pediatric nephrologist with Zenith Medical and Kidney Centre Abuja, Dr. Chukwunonso Epundu, discusses bedwetting or enuresis, in this interview with TOLUWALOPE KAREEMWhat is bedwetting?
Primary bedwetting is when a child has never attained continence at any point in time since he or she was born.
Secondary bedwetting is when a child may have attained continence, stopped bedwetting at night for at least about six months and then suddenly starts bedwetting again.
For adults, most of the time you already know that it is an organic problem, so you find the root of the problem and solve it.
If the right thing is done, and the right approach is taken, the child will eventually stop bedwetting.

headline: Buhari reacts to death of Soun of Ogbomoso
summarized_story:

Part of the statement reads: “The President commiserates with the Government and people of Oyo State and especially the indigenes of Ogbomosoland on the demise of the frontline traditional ruler whose reign of 48 years reinforced the town as a land of peace, accommodating and a bastion of history and tradition.

headline: Yuletide: Ban on fireworks, other explosives still in force – Imo police

headline: EXCLUSIVE: Head Of Service Warns Ministries, Agencies Over Rising Lawsuits From Workers Against Buhari Government
summarized_story:

“In the light of the above development, all MDAs are strongly advised to follow due process in handling staff matters, especially disciplinary cases.

headline: Could Africa ditch cash?
summarized_story:
The era of cash could be drawing to an end as central bank-backed digital currencies (CBDC”s) takes root in Africa.
So far, it’s only Nigeria that has launched an official, state-backed digital currency – christened the eNaira – on the continent as more countries continue to express interest.
The Baobab Network has traced at least 60 cryptocurrency companies in Africa, with the majority (43 percent) of them headquartered in Nigeria, followed by South Africa (18 percent) and Kenya (11 percent).
This is affirmed by another comparative study by GSMA published in March 2021 showing more than half of 310 live mobile money services in 2020 across the globe were found in Africa.
With over 55 percent of the world’s mobile money services recorded in Africa and a significant population turning to e-wallets and cryptocurrency, the question now becomes whether the continent might ditch paper money altogether.

headline: More pain for Nigerian states as FAAC shrinks by N68bn in November
summarized_story:
More pain for Nigerian states as FAAC shrinks by N68bn in NovemberThe ability of Nigerian states and other tiers of government to meet their various obligations is under more risk as gross monthly distribution by the Federation Account Allocation Committee (FAAC) to the three tiers of government dropped by N68billion in November.
The continuous decline in Nigeria’s FAAC allocation to the three tiers of government is also due to the subsidy payment, according to market analysts.
